title: 114_s1990
content: The Act may be cited as the "Federal Computer Security Act" and includes definitions for key terms. The Act, known as the "Federal Computer Security Act," defines key terms related to federal computer systems, including terms like agency, covered agency, logical access control, and multi-factor logical access controls. The Act also requires an Inspector General report on federal computer systems. The Inspector General of each covered agency must submit a report on Federal computer systems within 240 days of the Act's enactment. The report should include details on logical access standards, including a list of controls and whether multi-factor authentication is used. The covered agency must provide a description of data security management practices, including software inventories, licensing agreements for security controls, and monitoring for threats on Federal computer systems. The covered agency must describe how they are using specified software, provide reasons for not using it if applicable, and outline policies for ensuring data security practices are implemented by entities providing services. The report may be based on existing audits or evaluations and can include a classified annex if necessary. The report submitted under this section shall be available to any Member of Congress upon request, in unclassified form with the possibility of a classified annex. SEC. 4 of the Act requires the Comptroller General to submit a report to Congress within a year, analyzing impediments to agency use of security software and devices. The report may include a classified annex but will be in unclassified form.
